functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

<document>
<title>Digital Songs</title>
<fragment>
* "Rolling in the Deep" by Adele holds the record for the most digitally downloaded song in a calendar year.[24]
* "Payphone" by Maroon 5 featuring Wiz Khalifa holds the record for the largest debut/overall sales week for a group for a digital song with 493,000 downloads.[25]
* "We Are Young" by Fun. featuring Janelle Monáe is the first song to log seven weeks of 300,000 or more in digital sales.[26]
* "Thrift Shop" by Macklemore and Ryan Lewis featuring Wanz is the first song to log eight and nine weeks of 300,000 or more in digital sales.[27]
* "Blurred Lines" by Robin Thicke featuring T.I. and Pharrell is the first song to log 10 weeks of 300,000 or more in digital sales and the first song to log four weeks of 400,000 or more in digital sales.
* "Somebody That I Used to Know" by Gotye featuring Kimbra is the first song to log three weeks of 400,000 or more in digital sales.

</fragment>
<fragment>
* "Hello" by Adele holds the record for the largest debut/overall sales week for a digital song with 1.112 million downloads and the largest non-debut sales week for a digital song with 635,000 downloads. It is the first song to debut with 1 million downloads sold in a week and to log two weeks of 600,000 in digital sales. It surpassed the 4 million mark in its thirteenth week, faster than any other song in digital history.
* "Lean on Me" by Bill Withers is the oldest song to reach number one on the Digital Songs chart. The song was released on April 21, 1972, and reached the top, following Withers' death, on the chart dated April 18, 2020.[28]


## Album records

[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
* "Party in the U.S.A." by Miley Cyrus and "Gangnam Style" by Psy hold the record of most weeks at number one on Digital Songs without topping the overall *Billboard* Hot 100, with six weeks each.[17]
* "I Gotta Feeling" by The Black Eyed Peas holds the record for the biggest-selling digital download in the U.S., with sales of over 8 million copies by 2012. The song was the first to surpass 6–8 million downloads.[18]
* "Low" by Flo Rida featuring T-Pain was the first song to surpass 4–5 million downloads. It was also named the Top Digital Song of the 2000s decade.[19]
* Soulja Boy's "Crank That (Soulja Boy)" was the first song to surpass 3 million downloads.[20]
* Daniel Powter's "Bad Day" was the first song to surpass 2 million downloads.[21]
* "Hollaback Girl" by Gwen Stefani was the first song in history to surpass 1 million downloads.[22]
* "Right Round" by Flo Rida holds the record for the largest debut/overall sales week for a male for a digital song with 636,000 downloads.[23]

</fragment>
<fragment>
This article is about the Billboard music chart. For digital music, see Music download.





![](image)Billboard logo (From 2013)
The **Digital Songs** or **Digital Song Sales** chart (previously named **Hot Digital Songs**)[1] ranks the best-selling digital songs in the United States, as compiled by Nielsen SoundScan and published by *Billboard* magazine. Although it originally started tracking song sales the week of October 30, 2004,[2] it officially debuted in the issue dated January 22, 2005, and merged all versions of a song sold from digital music distributors.[3] Its data was incorporated in the Hot 100 three weeks later. Since October 2004, digital sales have been incorporated into many of *Billboard*'s music singles charts.[4] The decision was based on the dramatic increase of the digital market while commercial single sales in a physical format were becoming negligible.[5]


The first number one song on the Digital Songs chart was "Just Lose It" by Eminem.[2]


</fragment>
<fragment>
18. **^** "Week Ending June 24, 2012. Songs: Elton & The Peas". *Yahoo Music Chart Watch*. June 27, 2012. Retrieved March 29, 2021.
19. **^** "Digital Songs of the decade". *Billboard.com*. Retrieved February 5, 2011.
20. **^** Grein, Paul (June 26, 2013). "Week Ending June 23, 2013. Songs: Miley's Comeback Hit | Chart Watch (NEW) - Yahoo Music". Music.yahoo.com. Retrieved November 9, 2013.
21. **^** Chart Watch Extra: Thank You, Daniel Powter | Chart Watch - Yahoo! Music
22. **^** Mitchell, Gail (December 17, 2005). "Green Day, 50 Cent Come Up Big In Vegas". *Billboard*. Vol. 117, no. 51. Nielsen Business Media, Inc. p. 21. ISSN 0006-2510.
23. **^** "Flo Rida Topples Single-Week Download Mark". *Billboard*. January 12, 2008. Retrieved November 9, 2013.
24. **^** "Rihanna, Lady Gaga and Adele break World Records with digital music sales". *Guinness World Records*. September 7, 2012. Retrieved August 14, 2020.

</fragment>
<fragment>
* Katy Perry became the first artist in digital history to sell 300,000 downloads with eight different songs: "Hot n Cold" (2008), "California Gurls" (2010), "Firework" (2010), "E.T." (2011), "The One That Got Away" (2011), "Part of Me" (2012), "Roar" (2013), and "Dark Horse" (2014).[42]
* Rihanna was named the Digital Songs Artist of the 2000s decade.[43]
* Adele is the only artist to have a song earn one million downloads in a week, with "Hello" (2015).[44]
* Ed Sheeran is the first artist to debut two songs at the top two spots for the same week: "Shape of You" and "Castle on the Hill" (both 2017).[45]
* Lauren Daigle holds the record for the highest-ever debut by a contemporary Christian artist. She achieved this when "You Say" (2018) debuted at number five on the chart.[46]

</fragment>
<fragment>
* *Teenage Dream* (2010) by Katy Perry holds the record for most digital number-ones from an album, with five. "California Gurls" featuring Snoop Dogg, "Teenage Dream," "Firework," "E.T." featuring Kanye West and "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" all topped the chart.
* *1989* (2014) and *Reputation* (2017) by Taylor Swift each had four digital number-ones on the chart. "Shake It Off", "Blank Space", "Out of the Woods", and "Bad Blood" reached number one from *1989*, while "Look What You Made Me Do", "...Ready for It?", "Gorgeous", and "Call It What You Want" topped the chart from *Reputation*.


## Artist records

[edit]

### Most number-one hits

[edit]

1. Taylor Swift (27)[29]
2. Nicki Minaj (16)[30]
3. Rihanna (14)[31]
4. Justin Bieber (13) (tie)[32]
4. Drake (13) (tie)[33]
6. BTS (12)[34]
7. Katy Perry (11) (tie)[35]
7. Eminem (11) (tie)[36]
7. Beyoncé (11) (tie)[37]
10. Bruno Mars (9)[38]
### Most weeks at number one

[edit]

* BTS was the first act to debut six songs in the top 10 and to occupy the top six spots for the same week. They achieved this in 2020 with "Life Goes On", "Blue & Grey", "Stay", "Telepathy", "Dis-ease" and "Fly To My Room", all tracks from their fifth Korean-language studio album, *Be* (2020).[47][48]
* Taylor Swift is the only artist to have debuted ten songs in the top-10 region simultaneously and the only act to hold the entire top-10 spots of a week, achieving it with tracks from her tenth studio album, *Midnights* (2022).[49]


## See also

[edit]

* Hot Digital Tracks
* Digital distribution

<document>
<title>Digital Songs</title>
<fragment>
* "Rolling in the Deep" by Adele holds the record for the most digitally downloaded song in a calendar year.[24]
* "Payphone" by Maroon 5 featuring Wiz Khalifa holds the record for the largest debut/overall sales week for a group for a digital song with 493,000 downloads.[25]
* "We Are Young" by Fun. featuring Janelle Monáe is the first song to log seven weeks of 300,000 or more in digital sales.[26]
* "Thrift Shop" by Macklemore and Ryan Lewis featuring Wanz is the first song to log eight and nine weeks of 300,000 or more in digital sales.[27]
* "Blurred Lines" by Robin Thicke featuring T.I. and Pharrell is the first song to log 10 weeks of 300,000 or more in digital sales and the first song to log four weeks of 400,000 or more in digital sales.
* "Somebody That I Used to Know" by Gotye featuring Kimbra is the first song to log three weeks of 400,000 or more in digital sales.

</fragment>
<fragment>
* "Hello" by Adele holds the record for the largest debut/overall sales week for a digital song with 1.112 million downloads and the largest non-debut sales week for a digital song with 635,000 downloads. It is the first song to debut with 1 million downloads sold in a week and to log two weeks of 600,000 in digital sales. It surpassed the 4 million mark in its thirteenth week, faster than any other song in digital history.
* "Lean on Me" by Bill Withers is the oldest song to reach number one on the Digital Songs chart. The song was released on April 21, 1972, and reached the top, following Withers' death, on the chart dated April 18, 2020.[28]


## Album records

[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
* "Party in the U.S.A." by Miley Cyrus and "Gangnam Style" by Psy hold the record of most weeks at number one on Digital Songs without topping the overall *Billboard* Hot 100, with six weeks each.[17]
* "I Gotta Feeling" by The Black Eyed Peas holds the record for the biggest-selling digital download in the U.S., with sales of over 8 million copies by 2012. The song was the first to surpass 6–8 million downloads.[18]
* "Low" by Flo Rida featuring T-Pain was the first song to surpass 4–5 million downloads. It was also named the Top Digital Song of the 2000s decade.[19]
* Soulja Boy's "Crank That (Soulja Boy)" was the first song to surpass 3 million downloads.[20]
* Daniel Powter's "Bad Day" was the first song to surpass 2 million downloads.[21]
* "Hollaback Girl" by Gwen Stefani was the first song in history to surpass 1 million downloads.[22]
* "Right Round" by Flo Rida holds the record for the largest debut/overall sales week for a male for a digital song with 636,000 downloads.[23]

</fragment>
<fragment>
This article is about the Billboard music chart. For digital music, see Music download.





![](image)Billboard logo (From 2013)
The **Digital Songs** or **Digital Song Sales** chart (previously named **Hot Digital Songs**)[1] ranks the best-selling digital songs in the United States, as compiled by Nielsen SoundScan and published by *Billboard* magazine. Although it originally started tracking song sales the week of October 30, 2004,[2] it officially debuted in the issue dated January 22, 2005, and merged all versions of a song sold from digital music distributors.[3] Its data was incorporated in the Hot 100 three weeks later. Since October 2004, digital sales have been incorporated into many of *Billboard*'s music singles charts.[4] The decision was based on the dramatic increase of the digital market while commercial single sales in a physical format were becoming negligible.[5]


The first number one song on the Digital Songs chart was "Just Lose It" by Eminem.[2]


</fragment>
<fragment>
18. **^** "Week Ending June 24, 2012. Songs: Elton & The Peas". *Yahoo Music Chart Watch*. June 27, 2012. Retrieved March 29, 2021.
19. **^** "Digital Songs of the decade". *Billboard.com*. Retrieved February 5, 2011.
20. **^** Grein, Paul (June 26, 2013). "Week Ending June 23, 2013. Songs: Miley's Comeback Hit | Chart Watch (NEW) - Yahoo Music". Music.yahoo.com. Retrieved November 9, 2013.
21. **^** Chart Watch Extra: Thank You, Daniel Powter | Chart Watch - Yahoo! Music
22. **^** Mitchell, Gail (December 17, 2005). "Green Day, 50 Cent Come Up Big In Vegas". *Billboard*. Vol. 117, no. 51. Nielsen Business Media, Inc. p. 21. ISSN 0006-2510.
23. **^** "Flo Rida Topples Single-Week Download Mark". *Billboard*. January 12, 2008. Retrieved November 9, 2013.
24. **^** "Rihanna, Lady Gaga and Adele break World Records with digital music sales". *Guinness World Records*. September 7, 2012. Retrieved August 14, 2020.

</fragment>
<fragment>
* Katy Perry became the first artist in digital history to sell 300,000 downloads with eight different songs: "Hot n Cold" (2008), "California Gurls" (2010), "Firework" (2010), "E.T." (2011), "The One That Got Away" (2011), "Part of Me" (2012), "Roar" (2013), and "Dark Horse" (2014).[42]
* Rihanna was named the Digital Songs Artist of the 2000s decade.[43]
* Adele is the only artist to have a song earn one million downloads in a week, with "Hello" (2015).[44]
* Ed Sheeran is the first artist to debut two songs at the top two spots for the same week: "Shape of You" and "Castle on the Hill" (both 2017).[45]
* Lauren Daigle holds the record for the highest-ever debut by a contemporary Christian artist. She achieved this when "You Say" (2018) debuted at number five on the chart.[46]

</fragment>
<fragment>
* *Teenage Dream* (2010) by Katy Perry holds the record for most digital number-ones from an album, with five. "California Gurls" featuring Snoop Dogg, "Teenage Dream," "Firework," "E.T." featuring Kanye West and "Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)" all topped the chart.
* *1989* (2014) and *Reputation* (2017) by Taylor Swift each had four digital number-ones on the chart. "Shake It Off", "Blank Space", "Out of the Woods", and "Bad Blood" reached number one from *1989*, while "Look What You Made Me Do", "...Ready for It?", "Gorgeous", and "Call It What You Want" topped the chart from *Reputation*.

[edit]

<fragment>
* BTS was the first act to debut six songs in the top 10 and to occupy the top six spots for the same week. They achieved this in 2020 with "Life Goes On", "Blue & Grey", "Stay", "Telepathy", "Dis-ease" and "Fly To My Room", all tracks from their fifth Korean-language studio album, *Be* (2020).[47][48]
* Taylor Swift is the only artist to have debuted ten songs in the top-10 region simultaneously and the only act to hold the entire top-10 spots of a week, achieving it with tracks from her tenth studio album, *Midnights* (2022).[49]

msg.name: search

msg.content:
Based on the search results, I can identify some of the highest-selling digital singles, but the information about their record labels isn't directly provided in the Wikipedia article. Here are some of the notable digital sales achievements mentioned:

1. "I Gotta Feeling" by The Black Eyed Peas - Over 8 million copies by 2012 (first to surpass 6-8 million downloads)
2. "Low" by Flo Rida featuring T-Pain - First to surpass 4-5 million downloads
3. "Crank That (Soulja Boy)" by Soulja Boy - First to surpass 3 million downloads
4. "Bad Day" by Daniel Powter - First to surpass 2 million downloads
5. "Hollaback Girl" by Gwen Stefani - First to surpass 1 million downloads

Let me search specifically for the record labels of these songs.

function.name: search
function.arguments: {"query": "I Gotta Feeling Black Eyed Peas record label"}
